questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following are caused by single-gene mutations?
questions.explanation:
Mendelian disorders are caused by single-gene mutations. A mutation is defined as a permanent change in the genetic material that can result in altered 
protein function and phenotypic changes. Mutations that affect germ cells are transmitted to the progeny and can give rise to inherited 
diseases. Human genetic disorders can be broadly classified into three categories: • Single-gene mutations - these diseases usually follow the classic Mendelian pattern of 
inheritance. • Chromosomal disorders - These arise from the structural or numerical alteration in the 
autosomes and sex chromosomes. Like a monogenic disease, they are uncommon but associated 
with high penetrance. • Complex multigenic disorders - They are more common and are caused by interactions between 
multiple variant forms of genes and environmental factors. Such variations in genes are common 
within the population and are also called polymorphisms.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following diseases is associated with non-sense mutation?
questions.explanation:
A non-sense mutation is seen in  0 thalassemia. A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point 
mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA are of two types: 153 
Sold by @itachibot • Missense mutations: These involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases. It leads to the 
replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. These mutations alter the meaning 
of the sequence of the encoded protein. Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense 
mutations are again of two types: • Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the 
original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein. • Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with 
a biochemically different one. • Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature 
stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon 
(UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of  -globin gene 
translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of 
 -globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called  0 thalassemia. Option B: -thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent 
synthesis of -globin chains. Option C: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation. It occurs due 
to the replacement of the 6th glutamic acid by valine in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11. Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the 
red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to 
splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following traits are examples of co-dominance inheritance?
questions.explanation:
ABO blood group and HLA are both examples of codominant inheritance. In a codominant phenotype, alleles of a gene pair in a heterozygote are fully expressed. Thereby 
resulting in an offspring with a phenotype that is neither dominant nor recessive and both the 
alleles of a gene pair contributes to the phenotype. Mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive: • A dominant allele produces a dominant phenotype in individuals who have one copy of the 
allele, which can come from just one parent. • A recessive allele produces a recessive phenotype, in individuals who have two copies of the 
allele, one from each parent. The illustration below shows the codominant inheritance pattern of the blood group. 154 
Sold by @itachibot Hair colour, height, and skin color are polygenic traits.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the term for the phenomenon where a single mutant gene leads to many end-effects?
questions.explanation:
Pleiotropism is characterized by a single mutant gene, which may lead to many end effects. For example, in sickle-cell anemia, the point mutation in the gene not only predisposes the red 
blood cells to hemolysis but can also block the vessels. This leads to splenic fibrosis, organ 
infarcts, and bone changes. The numerous differing end-organ derangements are all related to the 
primary defect in hemoglobin synthesis. Option B: In variable expressivity, a trait is seen in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is 
expressed differently among them. Option C: Polymorphisms are caused by interactions between multiple variant forms of genes and 
environmental factors. Option D: Genetic heterogeneity refers to mutations at several genetic loci that may produce the 
same trait. An example of this is profound childhood deafness - an apparently homogeneous 
clinical entity that results from many different types of autosomal recessive mutations.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is autosomal dominant?
questions.explanation:
Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene. The primary defect is abnormal chondrocyte proliferation at the growth plate that causes 
development of short and thick bones. Clinical features: 155 
Sold by @itachibot • Short limbs • Normal trunk • Large head • Saddle nose • Exaggerated lumbar lordosis • Severe spinal deformity may lead to cord compression

questions.question:
Question 6: A 46-year-old woman presents with sudden onset chorea and behavioral changes. Genetic 
investigation reveals CAG repeats. What is the mode of inheritance of this disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Huntington's disease. It is an autosomal-dominant 
inherited disorder. Huntington disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and 
anticipation. It has an adult-onset and cell loss within a specific subset of neurons in the basal 
ganglia and cortex is seen. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, 
dementia, and behavioral changes.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for weakness and atrophy of distal limb musculature. 
Physical examination showing characteristic facies is given below. What is the mode of 
inheritance of this disease? 143 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image showing the characteristic hatchet facies are suggestive of myotonic 
dystrophy (dystonia myotrophica). It is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder affecting muscle 
function. There are mainly two types: • DM1 - In this type, the affected gene is DMPK, which codes for myotonic dystrophy protein 
kinase, a protein expressed predominantly in skeletal muscle. The gene is located on the long arm 
of chromosome 19. 156 
Sold by @itachibot • DM2 - It is caused by a defect of the CNBP gene on chromosome 3.

questions.question:
Question 8: After evaluation, a patient with the given finding is diagnosed with Bourneville disease. What 
is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC)/ Bourneville disease is an autosomal-dominant genetic disorder. TSC affects the differentiation, proliferation, and migration of cells early in development. This 
results in a variety of hamartomatous lesions that may affect virtually every organ system of the 
body. Two distinct genetic loci have been identified which are on chromosome 9 (TSC1) and on 
chromosome 16 (TSC2). The most common cutaneous manifestation of TSC is hypomelanotic macules (ash-leaf macules) 
and is observed in most children with tuberous sclerosis. It presents at birth or appears within the 
first few years of life and may fade or disappear in adulthood. The following image shows an ash-leaf macule.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance?
questions.explanation: Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 55-year-old man presents with a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. He was recently 
diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. His liver 
microscopy on Prussian blue staining is given below. What is the mode of inheritance of his 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. It is an autosomal recessive 
genetic disorder that involves the HFE gene. Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron accumulation that results in tissue damage. 
It consists of a triad of: 157 
Sold by @itachibot • Micronodular cirrhosis • Bronzing of the skin • Diabetes mellitus Diagnosis is by elevated levels of serum ferritin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, and 
confirmation by a gene assay. Note: Autosomal recessive disorders include almost all inborn errors of metabolism.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following patients has a disease showing the given mode of inheritance?

options.a: A 16-year-old boy with hundreds of adenomatous polyps throughout the colon
options.b: A 15-year-old boy with ataxia, cardiomegaly, scoliosis, and pes cavus
options.d: A 1-year-old boy with micro-thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections

questions.explanation:
The given pedigree chart is pointing towards an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. A boy 
with cardiomegaly, scoliosis, and pes cavus is suggestive of Friedreich’s ataxia. This is an 
autosomal recessive inherited disease, resulting from a mutation of a gene locus on chromosome 
9. The condition causes nervous system damage and movement problems. It usually begins in 
childhood and leads to impaired muscle coordination (ataxia) that worsens over time. Scoliosis, 
cardiomegaly, and foot problems may also develop. Option A: Hundreds of adenomatous polyps throughout the colon are suggestive of familial 
adenomatous polyposis(FAP) which is an autosomal-dominant inherited disorder. Option C: Vitamin D–resistant rickets is an X-linked dominant inherited disorder. Option D: A child with a triad of micro-thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections 
points towards Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome. It is an X-linked recessive inherited disorder.

questions.question:
Question 12: A newborn on routine head-to-toe examination was found to have ambiguous genitalia. 
Further investigations confirmed a deficiency of the 21-hydroxylase enzyme. What is the 
mode of inheritance of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It includes a group of 
autosomal recessive disorders, each of which involves a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the 
synthesis of cortisol, aldosterone, or both. The most common form is known to occur due to the deficiency of 21-hydroxylase, resulting from 
mutations or deletion of CYP21A.

questions.question:
Question 13: 146 
Sold by @itachibot A baby is brought to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Examination 
reveals a musty odor in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie's test is found to be positive. 
Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.a: The mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive
options.b: It is due to mutations in the PKU gene
options.c: It is an inborn error of amino acid metabolism

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU). It is caused by mutations in 
the PAH gene which encodes for phenylalanine hydroxylase. Phenylketonuria is the most common inborn error of amino acid metabolism. It is less commonly 
known as phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) deficiency. The mode of inheritance is autosomal 
recessive. 158 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 28-year old man presents to the clinic with complaints of lower back pain and passing dark 
red-colored urine. He was diagnosed with malaria and is on antimalarials for the past 3 days. 
The peripheral smear of the patient is shown below. What is the mode of inheritance of this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. It is 
the most common enzyme deficiency in humans, inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder. The 
gene that codes for G6PD is located in the distal long arm of the X chromosome at the Xq28 locus. The inheritance pattern is similar to that of hemophilia and color blindness, where males usually 
manifest the abnormality and females are carriers. Females may be symptomatic if they are 
homozygous or if inactivation of their normal X chromosome occurs.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with delayed developmental milestones. On 
examination, multiple lip lacerations and the given nail findings are noted. Laboratory 147 
Sold by @itachibot reports reveal hyperuricemia. What is the mode of inheritance in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome. It is an X-linked recessive inherited 
disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl 
transferase (HGPRT). Lesch–Nyhan syndrome and its variants are caused by mutations in the HPRT gene on the X 
chromosome. The disorder is associated with 3 major clinical elements: • Overproduction of uric acid (hyperuricemia) • Neurologic disability - intellectual disability and delayed milestones • Behavioral problems - self-mutilation (excessive biting of lips and nails)

questions.question:
Question 16: A 6-foot-5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early 
diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance 
of this condition. 148 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are 
suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant disorder. The family 
pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance. The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree 
chart. 159 
Sold by @itachibot Patients with Marfan syndrome have pleiotropic manifestations: • Skeletal systems - Tall and decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, 
hands, and fingers • Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches • Cardiovascular abnormalities - mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral 
regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and 
rupture. • Ocular - superio-temporal lens dislocation

questions.question:
Question 17: A 16-year-old girl with the given physical findings develops mitral regurgitation due to mitral 
valve prolapse. Eye examination reveals bilateral dislocation of the lens. This condition most 
commonly results from an inherited defect in which of the following proteins?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marfan's syndrome. It is due to the inherited defect of 
the protein fibrillin 1. Fibrillin is a major building block of microfibrils. This constitutes the structural components of 
the suspensory ligament of the ocular lens and serves as substrates for elastin in the aorta and 
other connective tissues. It occurs in two homologous forms: • Fibrillin-1: encoded by FBN1, mapped on chromosomes 15q21.1. Mutations cause Marfan's 
syndrome. • Fibrillin-2: encoded by FBN2, mapped on chromosomes 5q23.31. Mutations cause congenital 
contractural arachnodactyly.

questions.question:
Question 18: The most striking abnormalities of the Marfan syndrome are seen in which of the following 
systems?
questions.explanation:
160 
Sold by @itachibot Skeletal abnormalities are the most striking feature of Marfan syndrome. Skeletal abnormalities include: • Unusually tall, with exceptionally long extremities and long, tapering fingers and toes • The joint ligaments in the hands and feet are lax, suggesting that the patient is double-jointed. 
Typically, the thumb can be hyper-extended back to the wrist • The head is commonly dolichocephalic (long-headed) with bossing of the frontal eminences and 
prominent supraorbital ridges Spinal deformities include: • Kyphosis • Scoliosis • Rotation/slipping of the dorsal or lumbar vertebrae • Pectus excavatum (deeply depressed sternum) • Pigeon-breast deformity Ocular changes include bilateral subluxation or dislocation (outward and upward) of the lens, 
referred to as ectopia lentis. Cardiovascular lesions are the most life-threatening features of this disorder. The two most 
common lesions are: • Mitral valve prolapse • Dilation of the ascending aorta due to cystic medionecrosis The images given below show features seen in patients with Marfan's syndrome. 161 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: What is the most common cause of death in Marfan syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Cardiovascular lesions, like rupture of aortic dissections, are the most life-threatening features of 
the Marfan syndrome. The weakening of the media predisposes the aorta to an intimal tear. It may initiate an intramural 
hematoma that cleaves the layers of the media to produce aortic dissection. After causing the cleavage of the aortic layers for a considerable length, sometimes extending to 
the root of the aorta or down to the iliac arteries, the hemorrhage often ruptures through the 
aortic wall. Although mitral valve lesions are more frequent, they are clinically less important than aortic 
lesions. Loss of connective tissue support in the mitral valve leaflets makes them soft and billowy, 
creating a so-called floppy valve. 162 
Sold by @itachibot Valvular lesions, along with the lengthening of the chordae tendineae, frequently give rise to 
mitral regurgitation. Similar changes may affect the tricuspid and, rarely, the aortic valves.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following mode of inheritances is seen in Ehler–Danlos syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The mode of inheritance of Ehler–Danlos syndrome (EDS) encompasses two Mendelian patterns, 
namely: • Autosomal dominant • Autosomal recessive The biosynthesis of collagen can be disturbed by genetic errors that may affect any one of the 
numerous structural collagen genes or enzymes necessary for posttranscriptional modifications of 
collagen. Such molecular heterogeneity results in the expression of EDS as a clinically variable 
disorder, with varied patterns of inheritance.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 20-year-old woman presents with back pain and weakness. On examination, she is found to 
have lax skin. X-ray findings are shown below. Lab reports show a deficiency of lysyl 
hydroxylase. What is the most likely diagnosis? 150 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of the kyphoscoliotic form of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). 
This was previously known as Type VI EDS. The kyphoscoliotic form of EDS is caused by the deficient activity of the enzyme 
procollagen-lysine, 2-oxoglutarate 5-dioxygenase 1 (PLOD1, or lysyl hydroxylase 1). It is a generalized connective tissue disorder characterized by: • Friable hyperextensible skin • Thin scars • Easy bruising • Generalized joint laxity • Severe muscular hypotonia at birth • Progressive scoliosis may be present at birth or may develop within the first year of life

questions.question: Question 22: What type of collagen is involved in the classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Classic Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (EDS) type involves type V collagen (defects in genes COL5A1 
and COL5A2). Types I and II of EDS are termed as classic forms. Type I is severe, while type II is milder. It has an autosomal-dominant type of inheritance. Clinically, this type is characterized by skin and 
joint hypermobility, atrophic scars, and easy bruising. 163 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: The dermatosparaxis type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is classified as:
questions.explanation: Dermatosparaxis type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is type VIIc.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following pair is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation: Spinal muscular atrophy has an autosomal recessive inheritance, not autosomal dominant.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 1-month-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to 
thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification was noted 
radiologically. Which of the following enzyme is deficient in this condition?

options.a: Affected infants are normal at birth
options.b: Neurons in the CNS, ANS, and retina are affected

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Wolman disease. It is due to a deficiency of the lysosomal acid 
lipase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive disease. It leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides. It presents in the first few 
weeks of life with: • Failure to thrive • Vomiting • Abdominal distention • Steatorrhea • Hepatosplenomegaly • Hyperlipidemia • Extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life. 164 
Sold by @itachibot Lysosomal and Glycogen Storage Diseases
